bibl.title: Martin Lawson vs. King County. Writ of Habeaus Corpus
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: Third Judicial District of Washington Territory

div1.p: United States of America Third Judicial District of Washington Territory

In the matter of the complaint Martin Lawson, John Strom, Christ Anderson, Thomas Henward, Ellias Krebs, Edward Haquer, John Nickels, Peter Nelson, and Victor Martinson. Marines on board the American ship or vessel "War-Hawk" for a writ of Habeas Corpus
To the Honorable Joseph R. Lewis the Judge of the Third Judicial District of Washington Territory.
The complaint of Martin Lawson, John Strom, Christ Anderson, Thomas Henward, Ellias Krebs, Edward Haquer, John Nickels Peter Nelson, and Victor Martinson respectfully shows

That the said Martin Lawson, John Strom, Christ Anderson, Thomas Henward, Ellias Krebs, Edward Haquer, John Nickels, Peter Nelson, and Victor Martinson are and each of them is unlawfully imprisioned detained confined and restrained of their Liberty. by L. V. Wyckoff Deputy United States Marshall at the city prison of the city of Seattle in King County in the Territory of Washington
That the said imprisonment detention confinement and restraint are illegal and that the illegally thereof consists in this to writ:

That the said plaintiffs herein were mariners on board of the american ship War Hawk on the ninth day of December A. D. 1876. That on the said ninth day of December 1876 while said plaintiffs were on board the said ship in the performance of their duty as mariners thereon. They the said plaintiffs and all of them, were taken into the custody and render the control of the said L. V. Wyckoff Deputy United States Marshal as aforesaid, and by the said Deputy Marshal were then unlawfully imprisioned detained confined and restrained of their liberty at the city jail in the city of Seattle aforesaid since which time the said plaintiffs have been so unlawfully restrained of their liberty by the said Deputy Marshal.
That the said Deputy Marshal arrested the said plaintiffs and each and all of them and so unlawfully detained them of their liberty

under and by virtue of a warrants of arrest issued to the said Deputy marshal by one D. S. Smith who claims to be a Justice of the Peace in and for King County aforesaid, which said warrants were dated the 9th day of December A. D. 1876, and charging that the said plaintiffs and each of them did desert from the american ship War-Hawk, and commanding the said Deputy Marshal forthwith to apprehend the said plaintiffs and each of them and to bring and each of them before him the said D. S. Smith to be dealt with according to law, and that the said Smith signed the said warrants of arrest as "Justice of the peace", That upon the said ninth day of December A. D. 1876 the said Smith was not Justice of the Peace in and for said King County or elsewhere, nor was he vested by law with any power or authority whatsover to issue the said warrants of arrest or warrants of arrest of any nature or character warrnts of arrest, nor since the said ninth day of December 1876 has the said Smith possessed such authority or power, or the reason that at the general election on the 7th day of November one D. W. Seely and one C.C. Perkins were duly elected and have duly qualified as successors to said Smith under R. Scott and justices of the peace in and for King County, Seattle precinct and has thereupon such proceedings were had before the said Smith, that upon

That the said Smith has held the said office of Justice of the Peace for the period of the years and more prior to the election and qualification of the said D.W Judge and C. C. Perkins and prior to the said 9th day of of December A. D. 1876 that the said Smith daily qualified and entered upon the discharge of this duties as justice of the peace in said King County on the 14th day of November A. D. 1874, That said C. C. Perkins as such justice of the peace on the 16th day of November A. D. 1876

the fourteenth day of December aforesaid the said Smith, unlawfully acting as Justice of the Peace as aforesaid unlawfully committed the said plaintiff and each and all of them to the common jail of the city of the city of Seattle King County aforesaid until the Master of the said ship "War Hawk" where the alleged offense of detention from the said ship "War-Hawk" shall require their discharge That the said plaintiffs petitioners shipped on bound entered into of the said ship "War Hawk" on to wit the 15th day of November A.D. 1876 for a voyage to the port of Port Discovery in Washington Territory , from the Port of San Francisco in the State of California, for a cargo of lumber and back again to the said Port of San Francisco, that the said plaintiffs petitioners alleges that they or any of them did not make and sign any shipping articles or mariners contract before or at the time they entered into the service of the said ship

That the said ship War-Hawk instead of proceeding to the said Port of Port-Discovery and there attaining a cargo of lumber, as the said plaintiffs petitioners had been informed she would do, proceeded directly from the said port of San Francisco to the said
port of Seattle aforesaid That on the said seventh day of December A. D. 1876 while the said ship "War-Hawk" was lying at the said port of Seattle the master of the said ship although abundantly able so to do neglected and refused to furnish or cause to be furnished to said plaintiffs or any of them sufficient food, either in quantity or quality, and has since said seventh day of December neglected and refused to furnish or cause to be furnished to the said plaintiffs any suitable food.

That said ship leaks badly and totally unseaworthy when lader with a cargo of coal, with which she is now being That upon the said grounds, that the said plaintiffs have never made and signed any shipping articles or mariners contract to preform service upon the said ship. That there has been a material deviation in the voyage of the said ship, that there has been an insuffuiencey of food furnished the said plaintiffs, and that the said ship is unseaworthy, plaintiffs allege that they cannot be compelled to perform service on board the said ship or be punished in any manner for desertion therefrom-

Wherefore said plaintiff pray that a writ of Habeas Corpus may be granted directed to the said L. V. Wyckoff Deputy Marshal as aforesaid commanding him to have the bodies of the said Martin Lawson, John Strom, Christ Anderson, Thomas Henward, Ellias Krebs, Edward Haquer, John Nickels, Peter Nelson, and Victor Martinson before your Honor at a time and place therein to be specified to do and receive what shall than and there be considered by your Honor concerning this together with the time and cause of said plaintiffs detention, and said writ, and that these plaintiffs may be restored to their liberty.
Martin Lawson
John Strom
Christ Anderson
Thomas Henward
Ellias Krebs
Edward Haquer
John Nickels
Peter Nelson
Victor Martinson
White & Nash and
N.R. Andrews
Attorneys for Plaintiffs

On the fourteenth day of December A. D. 1876 personally appeared, Martin Lawson, John Strom, Christ Anderson, Thomas Henword, Ellias Krebs, Edward Haquer, John Nickels, Peter Nelson and Victor Martinson, who each and all of them made oath to me that they all are the plaintiffs named in the foregoing complaint that they here each heard the said complaint and know the contents thereof, are believe the same to be true.
Before me December 14th A. D. 1876 Beniah Brown Deputy Clerk 3rd Jud. Dist. W.T.
